dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Tiffany Dufu, Kerry Whorton Cooper, Rachel Carlson, Maria Bruno, and Stephanie Ruhle—that's a powerhouse lineup from the Forbes Women's Summit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tiffany Dufu, Kerry Whorton Cooper, Rachel Carlson, Maria Bruno, and Stephanie Ruhle-that's a powerhouse lineup from the Forbes Women's Summit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson was joined on-stage by Rothy's President Kerry Whorton Cooper, The Cru Founder & CEO Tiffany Dufu, MSNBC anchor Stephanie Ruhle and Vanguard's Head of U.S. Wealth Planning Research Maria Bruno.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Guild Education, um, the company they were talking about, is based in Boulder. They're helping huge employers like Lowe's and Taco Bell with retention through education programs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Guild Education, um, the company they were talking about, is based in Boulder. They're helping huge employers like Lowe's and Taco Bell with retention through education programs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Rachel Carlson mentioned that when companies invest in frontline workers, they see higher retention, better recruitment—it's a win-win.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Rachel Carlson mentioned that when companies invest in frontline workers, they see higher retention, better recruitment-it's a win-win.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But Stephanie Ruhle brought up a really interesting counterpoint—she said analysts on earnings calls never ask about the "good" a company is doing. So why are so many companies doing this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Stephanie Ruhle brought up a really interesting counterpoint-she said analysts on earnings calls never ask about the good a company is doing. So why are so many companies doing this?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Carlson argued that it's not just altruism—CEOs are seeing real profit lifts, better recruitment, uh, stronger retainment. It's impacting the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Carlson argued that it's not just altruism-CEOs are seeing real profit lifts, better recruitment, uh, stronger retainment. It's impacting the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the scale is massive—Guild serves 3 million employees! They've even raised over $72 million in funding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the scale is massive-Guild serves three million employees! They've even raised over seventy two dollars million in funding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to serving 3 million employees, the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But one thing that stood out to me was how this mostly focuses on frontline workers—cashiers, restaurant staff—63 million of whom need more education to keep up with automation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But one thing that stood out to me was how this mostly focuses on frontline workers-cashiers, restaurant staffminus sixty three million of whom need more education to keep up with automation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Walmart's program, Live Better U, only charges employees like a dollar fifty a day after aid. That's pretty accessible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and Walmart's program, Live Better U, only charges employees like a dollar fifty a day after aid. That's pretty accessible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, there's a gap—gig workers, like Lyft drivers, can't get the same tuition help because of tax code restrictions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, there's a gap-gig workers, like Lyft drivers, can't get the same tuition help because of tax code restrictions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might. That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That feels like a huge hurdle. Lobbying to change that could be Guild's next big challenge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That feels like a huge hurdle. Lobbying to change that could be Guild's next big challenge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's fascinating how education benefits are becoming a core part of corporate strategy, not just a perk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's fascinating how education benefits are becoming a core part of corporate strategy, not just a perk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And it's not just about feeling good—it's driving real results for these companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And it's not just about feeling good-it's driving real results for these companies.
